data.enText: a tool like a large spoon with a deep bowl, used for picking up substances in powder form like flour, or for serving food like ice cream
the amount picked up by a scoop

data.chText: 抢先报道的新闻；独家新闻
data.enText: a piece of important or exciting news that is printed in one newspaper before other newspapers know about it

data.chText: （尤指详情鲜为人知的）最新消息
data.enText: the latest information about sb/sth, especially details that are not generally known

data.chText: 我得知有关他新女友的最新内幕消息。
data.enText: I got the inside scoop on his new girlfriend.
to move or lift sth with a scoop or sth like a scoop

data.chText: 她用勺把冰激凌舀到他们的碗里。
data.enText: She scooped ice cream into their bowls.

data.chText: 他把桌上的钱一把抓起来。
data.enText: He quickly scooped the money up from the desk.
First, scoop a hole in the soil.
to move or lift sb/sth with a quick continuous movement
She scooped the child up in her arms.
to publish a story before all the other newspapers, television companies, etc.

data.chText: 这家报纸获得内部消息，抢在所有竞争对手之前发表了。
data.enText: The paper had inside information and scooped all its rivals.

data.chText: 获取，赢得（一大笔钱或丰厚的奖品）
data.enText: to win sth, especially a large sum of money or a prize

example: he used a scoop to serve the ice cream

tr: the shovel or bucket of a dredge or backhoe
a news report that is reported first by one news organization
example: he got a scoop on the bribery of city officials

tr: the quantity a scoop will hold
a hollow concave shape made by removing something

example: the goal was to best the competition

tr: take out or up with or as if with a scoop
example: scoop the sugar out of the container

value.def: If you scoop a person or thing somewhere, you put your hands or arms under or round them and quickly move them there.

example.ex: Michael knelt next to her and scooped her into his arms.
example.tran: 迈克尔挨着她跪下，一下把她揽入怀里。

value.tran: (敏捷地)抱起，拿起，捡起,拽过来

value.def: If you scoop something from a container, you remove it with something such as a spoon.

example.ex: ...the sound of a spoon scooping dog food out of a can.
example.tran: 用勺子从罐子里舀狗粮的声音

value.def: A scoop is an object like a spoon which is used for picking up a quantity of a food such as ice cream or an ingredient such as flour.

example.tran: 一个吃冰激凌的小勺儿

posc.def: A scoop of food is the amount that a scoop will hold.

example.ex: She gave him an extra scoop of clotted cream.
example.tran: 她多给他加了一勺浓缩奶油。

value.def: You can use scoop to refer to an exciting news story which is reported in one newspaper or on one television programme before it appears anywhere else.

example.ex: ...one of the biggest scoops in the history of newspapers.
example.tran: 报业史上最大的独家新闻之一

value.tran: 抢先报道的新闻;独家新闻

value.def: If a newspaper scoops other newspapers, it succeeds in printing an exciting or important story before they do.

example.ex: All the newspapers really want to do is scoop the opposition.
example.tran: 所有报社真正想做的就是比对手抢先报道。

value.def: If you scoop a prize or award, you win it.

example.ex: ...films which scooped awards around the world.
example.tran: 在全世界赢得各种奖项的影片

value.tran: 获取，赢得，捧走(奖金或奖项)

value.def: If something such as a dress has a scoop neck or a scooped neck, the neck has the shape of a wide, deep curve at the front.
